section.name: Samples quality control tests
section.p: User can add samples tests to be performed in this steps. The order of the parameters in the Aozan configuration file will be reused in the report generated by this step. Each test can use several parameters and contains always an "enable" property to activate the test. Usually a property named "interval" exists for each test, however if this property is not set, the value will be computed but not checked if it is the correct interval. You will find below all the parameters for all the available tests in Aozan.
For the quality control sample test, the report brings together three source of data :

li.a: Data supplied by the demultiplexing step

subsection.name: Sample quality tests from demultiplexing step

tr.td: Interval for valid values of rawclusterssamples
Interval for valid values of pfclusterssamples
Interval for valid values of percentpfsample
Interval for valid values of percentinlanesample depend on sample count in lane. interval is set according to the theoretical percent (1.0/sampleCount)
Interval for valid values of percentq30
Interval for valid values of meanqualityscorepf
Enable recoverablerawclusterssamples test : compute raw cluster can be recovery from undetermined fastq file with more one mismatch that use for demultiplexing step (maximum at 2).
Interval for valid values of recoverablerawclusterssamples
Enable recoverablepfclusterssamples test : compute passing filter cluster can be recovery from undetermined fastq file with more one mismatch that use for demultiplexing step (maximum at 2).
Interval for valid values of recoverablepfclusterssamples
Enable linkreportrecoverycluster test: link to report HTML

subsection.p: The explanation to construct intervals is here.

subsection.name: Sample quality tests from FastQC
subsection.p: Aozan launch FastQC on each sample (using parallel computation) and creates a report file including the thresholds fixed for quality controls.
If no FastQC test property is set, FastQC will not be launch on FastQ data.

tr.td: Specifies a file path which contains the list of contaminants to screen overrepresented sequences against that override the default list of contaminants. The file must contain sets of named contaminants in the form name[tab]sequence. Lines prefixed with a hash will be ignored. (FastQC parameter)
Specifies the length of Kmer to look for in the Kmer content module. Specified Kmer length must be between 2 and 10 (FastQC parameter)
Disable grouping of bases for reads >50bp. (FastQC parameter)
Path to a specific adapter file, replace default file. (FastQC parameter)
Path to a specific limits file, replace default file. (FastQC parameter)
Use exponential base groups in graph. (FastQC parameter)
Option for filtering bad Illumina FASTQ entries. (FastQC parameter)
Run FastQC on undetermined indices samples, default at false.
Run FastQC on nanopore technology which use Fast5 format file instead of FASTQ, default at false.

subsection.p: An example of table built with sample quality tests

img.alt: example on report with demultiplexing and fastqc data

subsection.p: It contains an additional FastQC step named "Bad tiles" that search tiles with BMS (Bottom Middle Swath) issues with Illumina flowcell v3. During the Quality Control development phase of the project with the new V3 chemistry, we set up a new FastQC module in order to detect bad tiles caused by the BMS problem.
Example of module ‘Bad tiles’:

The module overrepresented sequences in FastQC. The output of ‘Overrepresented Sequences’ module from FastQC has been improved for sequences not found in contaminant list. We (optionally) launch a blast on sequences with ‘no hit’ source. The report prints the best hit.

tr.td: Enable the blast search if not hit found for an overrepresented sequence
Path to blastn, it can run blastn from ncbi-blast+ or blastall
Path to the database nt (where is located nt.nal file)
Blast parameters. DO NOT use the following blast options: -d (blastn), -db (path to database), -outfmt (output type, must be in xml) and -num-threads (number processor)

subsection.p: A Docker container can be use to launch Blast. When the Docker usage is enable for Blasted, Blast2 2.2.26 will be use.

tr.td: Use Docker container to launch Blast

subsection.p: Example of new module ‘Overrepresented sequences’:

img.alt: module overrepresented sequences with results from blastn

subsection.name: Sample quality tests from contamination detection
subsection.p: Aozan includes a fast Java FastQ Screen implementation. This module maps reads samples on a list of reference genomes for assessing sample contamination and the ratio of the excepted genome in the sample. It creates a report file with values for each genome.

This step assesses the sample contamination from the FASTQ files. To do this, Aozan uses the FastQ Screen strategy. FastQ Screen allows to screen a library of sequences in Fastq format against a set of sequence databases.

The FastQ Screen code has been rewritten for Aozan and additional values are now calculated. Here we use bowtie to align reads on genomes or on contaminant databases like adapter sequences, PhiX and ribosomes databases. Moreover it aligns reads samples on the genome defined in the casava sample sheet file.

To avoid too long computation, the mapping on genomes is limited to a small set of the reads of the FASTQ files. By default 200,000 reads PF (passing illumina filters) are used for each sample (It's enough for estimate the contamination in a sample).
Aozan reuses Eoulsan to handle alignments and especially the repository system for genomes and genomes indexes.
If no FastQ Screen test property is set, FastQ Screen will not be launch on FASTQ data.
subsection.h5: General configuration for launch the mapper

tr.td: Path to the file which make the correspondence between genome name in casava samplesheet file and the genome name reference used for identified index of bowtie. If a genome's name doesn't exist in the alias file, it is added at the end of the file

Path to the genomes descriptions repository. The genome description file contains some basic informations about the genome like the chromosome length. The repository allow to avoid useless genome sequence parsing once it has been already parsed in a previous run
Path to the genomes indexes repository
List of reference genomes used per default for fastqscreen
In a next version, it will be possible to choice between bowtie and bowtie2. Per default, call bowtie.
Arguments of the mapper, in mode paired added ‘--maxins 1000’
No of contamination detection on control lane
If true for a run paired-end, the detection contamination concerns only the reads R1, same value are assigned for reads R2
Number of reads included in temporary FASTQ files create for the mapping. Only the reads with passing filtered illumina are selected. If value is set to -1, all reads in the FASTQ files will be used
The temporary FASTQ files are created by parsing at most this maximum number of reads in the FASTQ file source. If value is set to -1, it browses all the entries of the FASTQ files
Path to a specific stylesheet file to edit the fastqscreen report html, instead of the file per default
Run FastqScreen on undetermined indices samples on all genomes available for the run
The report of quality control contains a column with the percent of reads mapped at least one reference genomes, except on genome sample test
The report of quality control contains a column with the percent of reads mapped for each reference genome test
Interval of valid values. If the genome is this of sample, the interval is reverse (ex: [0.9, 1])
The report of quality control contains a column with link to report fastqscreen file, save in quality control directory

subsection.p: The explanation to construct intervals is here.
The last column contains a link to the report html fastqscreen. An example of a report html of quality control with major values of fastqscreen :
An example of a report html fastqscreen with four reference genomes and the genome sample (mm10) :
The report exists in csv format.

List of values for each genome :
%Mapped : percent of reads which are mapped on this genome. It must be low for the genome reference of contamination and high for the genome of the sample).
%Unmapped : percent of reads which are not mapped on this genome.
%One_hit_one_library : percent of reads which are mapped with one hit on one genome.
%Multiple_hits_one_library : percent of reads which are multi-mapped on this genome.
%One_hit_multiple_libraries : percent of reads which are mapped with one hit on several genomes.
%Multiple_hits_multiple_libraries : percent of reads which are multi-mapped on several genomes.
NB : The genome of the sample serves as positive control.

List of values for all genomes :
% reads_unmapped_none_genome : percent of reads which are not mapped on none genomes tested. It must be high if the genome of the sample isn't used and low if it is used).
% reads_mapped_at_least_one_genome : percent of reads which are mapped on at least one genome.
% reads_mapped_except_genome_sample : percent of reads which are mapped on the genomes references of contamination, the genome of the sample is excluded.
X reads mapped / 200 000 reads processed.

subsection.name: Analysis undetermined clusters from demultiplexing.
subsection.p: The undetermined FASTQ files created by the demultiplexing step can be analyzed using 3 modules:

ul.li: The recoverable sample clusters module can suggest for each indices, the sample(s) and the number of clusters that can be recovered using a demultiplexing step with one more mismatch that the number of mismatches has been used in the demultiplexing step. This module create two files (one for the lanes, the other for the samples) that display for each index the potential sample(s) and the number of recoverable clusters found.
The FastQC module. Use the "qc.conf.fastqc.process.undetermined.samples" property to enable this module.
The FastqScreen module. Use the "qc.conf.fastqscreen.process.undetermined.samples" property to enable this module.

tr.td: Compute the passing filter clusters that can be recovered from the undetermined FASTQ files with one more mismatch that the number of mismatches used in demultiplexing step (the maximum number of mismatches is 2)
Interval for valid values for the recoverablepfclusterssamples test
Link to the HTML recoverable clusters report

subsection.p:
The two reports are generated in CSV and HTML formats:
Example of a recoverable clusters lanes report:
Example of a recoverable clusters sample report:
